turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Good night, papa.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Good night, my little darling.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Papa?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: One of the boys in the stable told Nelly that you've already bought my horse, and that it's at Doolan's farm, where Mick the groom is breaking it in.  Is that true, papa?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: What the devil?  What kind of fools do we have here?  Pottle, who told the lad this story?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I promise your lordship a good flogging if you even so much as go to Doolan's farm to see him.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Yes, papa.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Your bother is in America fighting the rebels.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Is he all right, papa?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Yes, he's fine.

turns.speaker: PATRICK
turns.text: Brooksy was better than you, papa, he used not to swear so, and he taught me many good things while you were away.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I made Sir William Cosgrove's acquaintance as usual at the play- table.  One could not but admire the spirit and gallantry with which he pursued his favorite pastime; for, though worn out with gout and a myriad of diseases, a cripple wheeled about in a chair, and suffering pangs of agony, yet you would see him every morning, and every evening at his post behind the delightful green cloth.

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Hang it, Mr. Roderick James, you have no more manners than a barber, and I think my black footman has been better educated than you; but you are a young fellow of originality and pluck, and I like you, sir.  because you seem determined to go to the devil by a way of your own.

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Indeed, you are right, sir.  Look at me.  Marriage has added forty years to my life.  I am dying, a worn-out cripple, at the age of fifty.  When I took off Lady Cosgrove, there was no man of my years who looked so young as myself.  Fool that I was! I had enough with my pensions, perfect freedom, the best society in Europe -- and I gave up all these, and married and was miserable.  Take a warning from me, Mr. Roderick, and stick to the trumps.  Do anything, but marry.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Would you have me spend my life all alone?

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: In truth, sir, yes, but, if you must marry, then marry a virtuous drudge.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: The milkmaid's daughter?

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Well, why not a milkmaid's daughter? No man of sense need restrict himself or deny himself a single amusement for his wife's sake; on the contrary, if he selects the animal properly, he will choose such a one as shall be no bar to his pleasure, but a comfort in his hours of annoyance.  For instance, I have got the gout; who tends me?  A hired valet who robs me whenever he has the power.  My wife never comes near me.  What friend have I?  None in the wide world.  Men of the world, as you and I are, don't make friends, and we are fools for our pains.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Sir William Cosgrove, with his complication of ills, was dying before us by inches.  He was continually tinkered up by doctors, and, what with my usual luck, he might be restored to health and live I don't know how many years.  If Cosgrove would not die, where was the use of my pursing his lady?  But my fears were to prove groundless, for on that very night, patient nature would claim her account.

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. James, have you done with my lady?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Come, come, sir.  I am a man who would rather be known as a cuckold than a fool.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I think, Sir William Cosgrove, you have had too much drink.  Your chaplin, Mr. Hunt, has introduced me into the company of your lady to advise me on a religious matter, of which she is a considerable expert.

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Gentlemen, see this amiable youth! He has been troubled by religious scruples, and has flown for refuge to my chaplin, Mr. Hunt, who has asked for advise from my wife, Lady Cosgrove, and between them both, they are confirming my ingenious young friend in his faith.  Did you ever hear of such doctors and such a disciple?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Faith, sir, if I want to learn good principles, it's surely better I should apply for them to your lady, and your chaplin than to you?

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: He wants to step into my shoes!  He wants to step into my shoes!

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Well, if my intentions are what you think they are -- if I do wish to step into your shoes, what then?  I have no other intentions than you had yourself.  Lady Cosgrove's wealth may be great, but am I not of a generous nature enough to use it worthily?  Her rank is lofty, but not so lofty as my ambition.  I will be sworn to muster just as much regard for my Lady Cosgrove as you ever showed her; and if I win her, and wear her when you are dead and gone, corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me?

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my wife so fond of me, that she is even now thinking of appointing a successor?  Isn't it a comfort to see her; like a prudent housewife, getting everything ready for her husband's departure?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, knight?

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps.  Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.  Who knows how long I may keep you waiting.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Sir, let those laugh that win.

turns.speaker: SIR WILLIAM
turns.text: I am sorry for you Mr. James.  I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting.  Had you not better to arrange with my doctor or get the cook to flavor my omelette with arsenic?  What are the odds, gentlemen, that I don't live to see Mr. James hang yet?

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Charming Schuvaloff.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Black-eyed Sczortarska.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Dark Valdez.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Do you expect me to believe that your lover brought you here tonight?

turns.speaker: VALDEZ
turns.text: Yes.  He brought me in his carriage, and he will call for me at midnight.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: And he doesn't care about me?

turns.speaker: VALDEZ
turns.text: He is only curious to know who you are.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: If his love were like mine, he would not permit you to come here.

turns.speaker: VALDEZ
turns.text: He loves me, as I love you.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Will he wish to know the details of this night?

turns.speaker: VALDEZ
turns.text: He will believe that it will please me if he asks about it, and I shall tell him everything except some circumstances which might humiliate him.

turns.speaker: RODERICK
turns.text: Tender Hegenheim.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Don't like 'em, don't eat 'em, don't make no damn difference to me.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You know that was like a quadruple negative?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Can I at least have a drink?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: It's ten thirty in the morning.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Yeah, if you've slept.

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: You know the law -- no liquor before noon. Could lose my license.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Don't you mean "don't need no liquor license not taken away from me"?

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Hurricane kept you up, too?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Yeah, and I could've used the sleep. I'm supposed to meet people here tonight, try and get some work going.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Bill Styles...

turns.speaker: BARTENDER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Old friend. Haven't talked to him in -- 911. Can I use your phone?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Don't you ever point a gun at me!

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I'm -- I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: A target, Kendall, cap a fucking target. What's wrong with you?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I thought I was gonna have an attack. Go into a fit and bite off my own tongue in the middle of the bayou. Childs could tell I wasn't right.

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Just safety your shit and get behind me, okay? I'll take care of this.

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Fuck, what the fuck is going on --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: What do we do?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Whoever it is isn't shooting at us...

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I don't want to go --

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Did -- did you --

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: It was the grenade you fucking idiot. Look at him!

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: What about Pike?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Maybe he'll be there. Either way, we have to go.

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: He is the only one unaccounted for.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Maybe he's dead too. Maybe you killed them both, Mueller --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: You framed-him...

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: None of that matters now. We got two dead bodies and a story that explains them. You're either with us, or against us -- which is it?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: This isn't our area. Whose area is this --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Can anybody hear me!

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Hey, I --  Holy fuck... holy fuck, what the fuck did you guys do?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: We found him like this --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: You killed him you fucking faggot --

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: We found him like this! Kendall was with me the whole -- Listen to me!

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: We got -- I don't know, we got separated

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Before or after the explosion?  Mueller --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: I don't know!

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Shut the fuck up, you fucking faggot, You just shut the FUCK UP.

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: HEY!

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: West was one thing, but this --

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Shut up, Mueller.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: We finished the course and came here, then heard an explosion --  Where's Pike?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: We don't know. West is dead.

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: What about you, wandering around alone? At least we have an alibi --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: What do you mean, alone?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Holy fuck... Holy fuck, what the fuck did you guys do?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: We found him like this...

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: Yeah, right...

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Shut up.  West's dead.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You too?

turns.speaker: CHILDS
turns.text: We can still come out of this okay. Pike got free, he got a gun, he came after us. That's the story.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I asked for a policeman.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You're under military arrest, it's not gonna happen. What's wrong with baseball?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: It's... too slow.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Well, it's a game of anticipation, that's the beauty.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I just don't like it.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: What do you like then?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I don't know... I like the Army.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: C'mon, Ray, everyone hates the Army during Basic. I'll tell you straight, I hated it here.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You did Basic here?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Fifteen years ago under Sergeant West. Piece of work, that guy. I remember, he used to have these two silver .45's with ivory handles and if you weren't quick enough, he'd knock you on the head with one of them. He still carry those guns?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: There's no need...

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: They're dead, aren't they?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Right. Now, I'm gonna go get you another donut and you think about whether you want to talk more, okay?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Why'd you ask for a cop, Ray?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I'm not telling you what happened.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Okay... but I would like to know about the other cadets. What they were like -- nice guys?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Some.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Tell me about them.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: And those were the guys who went on the exercise with you?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Yeah. And that's all I'm saying.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You smoke, Ray?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: This is one of those interrogation tricks, isn't it? You don't give me a cigarette till I tell you more.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: No, actually, I just left mine in the car and was hoping you had some.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Hey, Ray! Just had a nice talk with your buddy Kendall -- seems you killed three people!

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: That son of a bitch.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: That'd be my reaction too --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: He's lying.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Well, why didn't you say so? We'll just drop all your charges, then --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I'm serious --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Fuck "you're serious", Raymond, you got exactly zero truck with us; right now we'd take the word of a crackhead over yours, so if you've got something to say, say it.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Did Kendall tell you about the PX?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: So Childs made some side money, so what? People are dead, Ray, and the only one we have to blame is you --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I didn't shoot West --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Yeah, we know, Pike did.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I apologize --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You saw West's body.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Of course --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: And he'd been shot.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Yeah --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You shot Childs and Nunez.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: They would have killed us both. You want me to write a confession, I'll write a confession.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You saved Kendall's life --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: But not Pike's.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Raymond, for you to have any chance of coming out of this, we need to locate the other bodies and examine them to corroborate your testimony. Otherwise this is just another story --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Mr. Hardy, I joined the army for college money. I didn't ask for any of this -- I tried to do the right thing out there and people got killed. You say finding those bodies'll help me, then go find them. I don't want to die.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: We're not finished yet --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You wanna bet?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: We don't need the tapes --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Oh, you don't? What else do you have on me? You haven't found any bodies yet, have you?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: We've found all of them.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Not true, Cadet, I've got a gun --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Jesus!

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: He -- He made me do it --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Do what?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Hunting -- we had to hunt him --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I guess Nunez wasn't dead after all. He came after us with a vengeance.  You know the rest.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: And the bodies?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You won't find them. Won't find West, either. He's too good.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: I promised them I'd ask you where West and the others are...

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Washout rejects, guys he said were "dumbfucks too stupid to know they dead"...

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: He's telling the truth up to a point...

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Are you saying Sergeant West tried to kill you?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: No, ma'am, he just wanted us to quit. Making it through was kind of an honor. Some of the other guys on the base told us that if you could hack Section Eight, Command would consider you at the top of the class.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: That first night with Pike. I made the mistake of letting him sit down at around 0300.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Tell us about the other guys, the ones West weeded out.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: There were six of us...

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: He was sickly. Had that shaking thing, whatd'yacall it, epoxy?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Epilepsy.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Yeah. Spent half his time in the infirmary. Only reason he enlisted was his father. West didn't section him till last week.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: He said he worked there --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: No, did he tell you about it? About the business Childs ran?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: What business?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Pills, shots, you name it, Basic's a lot easier when you don't feel pain --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: The creek bed --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: What about the phosphorous grenade?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: One went off, yeah, but it didn't touch him -- I thought you knew this --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Back up.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Mueller was alone in the cabin?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Why didn't you tell us all this in the first place?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Would you have believed me?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Where's the cabin?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Don't know on a map. West told us it was there, we just found it. Maybe the hurricane took it away.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: You kept Kendall alive to corroborate your story and he did it all they way up to the end. You even gave him his own motive in case we decided to burn him, too.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Can't do that now, though, can you?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Is that what I did, now? And of course, you can prove all of it.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: We can prove that you're not Ray Dunbar. Impersonating a fellow Cadet is a court-martial in and of itself --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Did I ever claim I was Raymond Dunbar? Was I ever told to state my name rank and serial number for the record? No. You assumed who I was, because I was wearing this uniform. Don't believe me?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Ohhhh, I don't think so...

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: How do you know that?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Just a guess. Maybe they're not where they're supposed to be. Maybe somebody moved them. Habeas Corpus -- no bodies, no crime, and Nunez still plays as self defense. Face it detectives... you have nothing.

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: Cadet, what's your name!

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Sir, Dunbar, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: You know how to work a pistol, Dunbar?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: Dunbar you are to stand here and guard this nigger for the next twenty- four hours! He is not to be given food, water, or clothes! If he so much as moves, you are to blow his nigger brains out, is that clear?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: The rest of you, fallout for physicals!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: What the fuck is going on?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Your weapons, Sergeant.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: He wouldn't kill anybody...

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Oh, bullshit, he's a fucking convict. You know how much he hated West --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I hated West, Childs hated West, everyone with a goddamn brain hated West but that doesn't mean we killed him!

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Shut up.  Let me see your grenades.

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: We were each given three so whoever killed West will be missing one.

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Jesus, what happened?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: West... he's dead.

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Pike and I got separated... then I heard gunfire. Close.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: So did we. Why didn't you come?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: So you killed him?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Whose blood is that, Jay?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: West's. Any kindling for afire?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: What do you mean, West's?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: I mean I killed him.  Isn't that what we all wanted?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Where have you been, Jay?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Wandering through a hurricane trying to find this place. It's gettin' bad out there --  Where's West?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Roberto, what the fuck?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: We just want to check your pack --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You know it's not like that --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Do I?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Right?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: You gotta untie me.  I didn't do this thing, Ray.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You hated West more than any of us.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Maybe, but that don't make me a killer --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You're the only one missing a grenade.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Which anyone coulda taken out of my gear on the chopper. Were you watching your pack on the ride in?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Ray, this is my life here. I ain't gonna pretend I'm not happy West is gone, but you know I couldn't have done this. It's not in me.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: If not you, then who?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Mueller.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Oh, come on --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: We're sweeping our area and suddenly he's gone. Couple minutes later, phosphorous grenade pops off about a third of a click away --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: That's exactly what he says about you.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Who you gonna trust, Ray? Him or your friend?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You hated West, Mueller loved him --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Enough to go to prison? Childs' PX scam, Mueller was in on it --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Look in my pack.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Just look. Little pocket.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Combat grade morphine. Mueller sold it to me.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: You're lying --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Pull up my sleeve. Right arm.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Why... why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Becoming a morphine addict during Basic ain't exactly something you want to broadcast. Only Mueller and Childs know.

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: That still doesn't mean you didn't kill him.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: You saw West, right? How was he killed?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Full clip to the body --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: From up close or far away?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: His chest was hamburger --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: That's close range. You go full auto on a guy from close range, you're gonna be swimming in blood. Look at my uniform. Nothing.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Way I figure it, West must have found out about their little business and was gonna bust them, so they decided to get rid of him first...

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: They?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Mueller and Childs. One of them must've taken the grenade from my pack on the chopper...

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: I... I don't know...

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: What don't you know?

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: This is a lot of information to be getting... I have to think --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: There's no time to think, Ray, we gotta get out of here! You untie me, we grab the guns, get Kendall and Nunez, and make a run for it --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: No... no, we can just wait till we get back and then tell the M.P.'s --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: We wait and I'm a dead man. I got a black face, a criminal record, and over a hundred other cadets who'll testify how much I hated West -- my court martial will take six minutes. It's either me or them, Ray, and you gotta decide right now.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: A test will no doubt link you to the killing --

turns.speaker: DUNBAR
turns.text: Put it down!

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: You... I've seen you around the Base. But you...  You're not Army, are you?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Coast Guard, special detective detail. We feel this incident may have put the beaches of Florida at risk.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: That's it. You're that policeman with friends in low places. Tell me, how's Guissepe Torres doing these days? Those racketeering indictments must have really been a downer --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Levi, you got about four hours before armed men show up here, put you on a plane to Washington, and lock you in a very small dark room. I suggest you talk to us.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I've done nothing wrong.  I'm the victim here.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: But not the only victim, right?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: My, my, my, how did things turn so hostile so quickly? If I didn't know better, I'd say you two were out to get me.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: My father is a powerful man. Over the years he's used that power to protect me, in one form or another, from certain... unpleasantries.  I am a homosexual.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Senator Daddy must be thrilled.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: He is not, shall we say, wild about the idea. He has asked me on numerous occasions to be more discreet about my proclivities, and I have done my best to oblige him. However, in the last four weeks, I began a relationship with another cadet. What do you think of that?

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: I think you just blew "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" out of the fucking water.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: The Sergeant discovered this relationship and wanted me expelled. My father interceded, so instead, West Sectioned me and made sure every other cadet knew that I was gay.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Levi, I don't know if you're familiar with investigative work, but we have this little thing called "motive" and you just gave yourself one.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: You said you wanted to know what happened -- I'm telling you the truth.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: What happened to "degrees"?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I didn't kill him --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Then who did?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Maybe I shouldn't tell you that. Maybe I should tell you I wasn't scared at all. But I was...  Enough to almost kill him.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: But you didn't.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: No. Poetic justice, though.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: He admitted it.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Right in front of us. Mueller went after him but we held him back.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Why did he come back for you?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I honestly don't know. Maybe to have someone to cover for him. And I wish I could, but there's no doubt in my mind he killed those men.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Okay. I think that's it. He rises and walks to the door.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Mr. Hardy?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Somebody emptied a full clip into him --

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Stop.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: You tried to pin three stone murders on Dunbar --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: How many murders did you cover up? One? Five? Maybe an even ten.

turns.speaker: HARDY
turns.text: Can I go to jail for punching a guy who's been shot?
